titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George N. Huckins diary, 1858-1861
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, November 2021

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Diary (63 pages) kept while Huckins was a student at Baldwin University (now Baldwin-Wallace College) in Berea, and while serving several churches in northern Ohio. Short, introspective entries generally relate to his doubts about his qualifications as a minister and to his matrimonial prospects, with brief references to his school activities and studies, John Brown, James Buchanan, the election of Lincoln and the beginning of the Civil War, and slavery.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: George N. Huckins diary, 1858-1861, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, November 2021.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: George N. Huckins was a Methodist minister, resident of Cuyahoga County, Ohio.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Diary (63 pages) kept while Huckins was a student at Baldwin University (now Baldwin-Wallace College) in Berea, and while serving several churches in northern Ohio. Short, introspective entries generally relate to his doubts about his qualifications as a minister and to his matrimonial prospects, with brief references to his school activities and studies, John Brown, James Buchanan, the election of Lincoln and the beginning of the Civil War, and slavery.
